coredata.dc:title: Enabling lithium metal battery with flexible polymer/garnet type solid oxide composite electrolyte
coredata.dc:creator: Gu, Yuting
She, Shengxian
Hong, Zijian
Huang, Yuhui
Wu, Yongjun
coredata.dc:description: Polymer/garnet solid oxide composite electrolyte has been regarded as a promising solution for solid-state lithium metal battery. It has many advantages such as higher flexibility, lower density, relatively higher ionic conductivity and better contact with electrodes as compared to pure oxide electrolytes and pure polymer electrolytes. In this work, we report a poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) / Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) composite electrolyte with a facile synthesis route and all commercially available raw materials. This hybrid electrolyte exhibits overall outstanding properties, including wide electrochemical stability window (~5 V), superior mechanical properties with tensile strength over 13 MPa and Young's Modulus >50 MPa, relatively good room temperature ionic conductivity (3.2 × 10−4 S.cm−1) and good electrochemical performance (~150 mAh g−1 at 0.1C and 99% coulombic efficiency after 50 cycles).

EIS plots of CE0 (a) and CE15 (b) at different temperatures. (c) Ionic conductivities of the CEs with various weight fractions of LLZTO at different temperatures. (d) Arrhenius plots of the CEs.

head.ce:title: Enabling lithium metal battery with flexible polymer/garnet type solid oxide composite electrolyte

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: School of Materials Science and Engineering

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Polymer/garnet solid oxide composite electrolyte has been regarded as a promising solution for solid-state lithium metal battery. It has many advantages such as higher flexibility, lower density, relatively higher ionic conductivity and better contact with electrodes as compared to pure oxide electrolytes and pure polymer electrolytes. In this work, we report a poly(vinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) / Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 (LLZTO) composite electrolyte with a facile synthesis route and all commercially available raw materials. This hybrid electrolyte exhibits overall outstanding properties, including wide electrochemical stability window (~5 V), superior mechanical properties with tensile strength over 13 MPa and Young's Modulus >50 MPa, relatively good room temperature ionic conductivity (3.2 × 10−4 S.cm−1) and good electrochemical performance (~150 mAh g−1 at 0.1C and 99% coulombic efficiency after 50 cycles).

ce:section.ce:para: State-of-art solid-state batteries with solid electrolytes and high energy lithium metal anodes have been considered as the next generation energy technology to power electric vehicles and flights [1–7]. To date, various solid electrolyte systems have been investigated, including polymer electrolytes (i.e., PEO-based [8], PVA-based [9], PAN-based [10], PEC-based [11], PVDF-based [12,13], etc.) with lithium salts, pure ceramics such as oxides [14–16], nitrides [17], sulfides [18,19], as well as ceramic polymer composite electrolytes (CPCEs) [20–22]. Among them, CPCEs have attracted various attentions in the past few decades. As compared to the pure polymer electrolytes, CPCEs have many advantages such as higher ionic conductivity and elastic stiffness, which are essential to the suppression of lithium dendrite growth. Meanwhile, CPCEs have higher flexibility, better contact with electrodes and lower density with respect to the pure ceramic electrolytes [23–27]. However, there are also some key challenges for improving the performances of CPCEs, such as low ionic conductivity [28,29], poor interfacial contact [30–33] and low mechanical strength [34,35], etc. which largely hinder their practical applications.

Previously, many strategies have been used to tackle these issues. For instance, PEO-based polymers have been widely investigated as composite materials due to the low cost and high electrochemical window. Meanwhile, they suffer from low transference number and relatively low ionic conductivity (in the order of 10−5 S.cm−1) [36–39]. Many other polymer composite systems have also been studied, including poly(propylene carbonate) (PPC) [40–42], poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) [43–45], poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) [46] and poly(vinylidene fluoride-hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP) [47–49], etc. Among them, PVDF-HFP system has been widely used due to the high mechanical strength and good compatibility with lithium salts. On the other hand, the development of high-performance ceramic additives is also critical for improving the performances of the CPCEs. Ta-doped Li7La3Zr2O12 (LLZTO) has been widely investigated as the ceramic additives in CPCEs recently, owing to the superior ionic conductivity, good stability towards Li-metal and good mechanical properties [50–54]. However, to the best of our knowledge, most of the previous works on PVDF-HFP/LLZTO CPCEs focus only on improving some of these properties while ignoring other important factors.

Herein, we design a facile synthesis route for PVDF-HFP/LLZTO garnet composite electrolyte with all commercially available raw materials and apply it in solid-state lithium metal-based battery. This highly flexible composite electrolyte shows overall excellent performances, including: superior electrochemical stability window (4.98 V), high mechanical strength (tensile strength >13 MPa and Young's modulus >50 MPa), good ionic conductivity (3.2 × 10−4 S.cm−1) and good electrochemical performance (~150 mAh g−1 at 0.1C and 99% coulombic efficiency after 50 cycles). The enhanced performance is further discovered to be related to the use of PVDF-HFP in both composite electrolyte and cathode materials, which could lower the interfacial resistance between the electrolyte and cathode.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of the PVDF-HFP/LLZTO composite electrolytes
ce:section.ce:para: The synthesis procedure is given in Fig. 1 . First, 3 g PVDF-HFP (Mw = 500,000, Solvay, dried in vacuum at 80 °C for 24 h) and 1 g LiTFSI (99%, Aladdin) were dissolved together in 27 mL N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (99.9%, Aladdin). The solution was placed in water bath at 50 °C and magnetically stirred for 6 h to form a homogeneous solution. Then Li6.4La3Zr1.4Ta0.6O12 nanoparticles (LLZTO, purchased from Hefei Kejing Materials Technology, Co. Ltd., with particle size ranging from 300 nm to 500 nm) were added to the above solution and continued to stir for another 6 h. Different weight ratio of LLZTO, namely 0, 10, 15, 20 and 30 wt% (denoted as CE0, CE10, CE15, CE20 and CE30, respectively), were added for comparison. Consequently, the mixture was cast onto a clean glass plate, and the thickness of the prepared electrolyte membrane was controlled by adjusting the height of a doctor blade. Thin films of composite electrolytes were obtained by further drying under vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h to remove DMF solvent. Finally, the as-prepared CE membranes were cut into circular shapes and stored in a glove box (< 0.01 ppm H2O and O2).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of the cathode and assembly of cells
ce:section.ce:para: Two types of cathodes were investigated in this study, i.e., a conventional LiFePO4 cathode (LFP) with 80 wt% LFP, 10 wt% PVDF and 10 wt% Super P and a new LFP cathode (denoted as LFP-new) with 75 wt% LFP, 10 wt% PVDF-HFP, 10 wt% Super P and 5 wt% LiTFSI. The LiTFSI added in LFP-new could improve the ionic conductivity of cathode. The cathode materials were mixed in an agate mortar. After being ground for 10 min, they were dissolved in NMP (99.5%, Aladdin) solvent and stirred for 6 h to obtain a homogeneous slurry. Then the mixture was cast onto an aluminum current collector, heated at 80 °C for 12 h and later cold-pressed under 400 MPa. The cathode electrodes were finally obtained after vacuum dried at 80 °C for another 4 h. The mass loading of LFP in the cathode pellet is ~2 mg cm−2.

The standard coin cells (CR2025) were assembled using lithium foil as anode, LFP with different binders as cathode and CE membrane as electrolyte in the argon-filled glove box. To improve the interface contact and minimize the interfacial impedance of CE membrane and electrodes, 10 μL liquid electrolyte (1.0 M LiPF6 in EC: DMC =1:1 Vol%) was added to the surface of CE membrane.

Structure characterizations were performed to unveil the crystal structure and microstructure of the obtained materials. The crystal structures of LLZTO powder, PVDF-HFP powder and composite electrolytes were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) in the range of 5–90°. The morphologies and compositions of the composite electrolytes were observed by a field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4800, 5 kV) equipped with energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS). The thermal properties of the composite electrolytes were tested with thermogravimetry-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC, NETZSCH) at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from room temperature to 700 °C under nitrogen (N2) atmosphere. The mechanical properties of the obtained membranes were characterized by a universal material testing machine (Zwick/Roell Z005). The experiments were conducted in a tensile mode at a stretching speed of 5 mm min−1 at room temperature.

Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurement was used to determine ionic conductivity with stainless steel (SS)/CE/SS cell. Alternating-current (AC) impedance measurements were carried out using an impedance analyzer (Novocontrol Technologies) with temperature range from 25 °C to 80 °C and frequency range between 1 Hz and 1 MHz, respectively. The ionic conductivity (σ) was calculated from the following equation:
(1)
σ =
d RS
where d is the thickness of the electrolyte membrane, R represents the measured resistance, and S is the area of the stainless steel electrode [42].

The electrochemical stability of the composite electrolyte was investigated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) with Li/CE/SS cell. The tests were performed on an electrochemical workstation (IVIUM Technologies) at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 over a potential range of 2–6 V at room temperature.

The lithium-ion transference number (t
Li + ) of the composite electrolyte was tested with symmetrical Li/CE/Li cell by a combined measurement of AC impedance and direct-current (DC) polarization on the same electrochemical workstation with LSV. The t
Li + was calculated by Eq. (2): [55,56].
(2)
t
Li +
=
I SS
∆ V −
I 0
R 0
I 0
∆ V −
I SS
R SS
where ∆V is the applied 5 mV DC voltage, I 0 and I
SS represent initial and steady current value. Whereas R 0 is the initial resistance and R
SS is the steady-state resistance, which can be obtained before and after the polarization, respectively.

The interface stabilities of composite electrolytes against Li metal were determined by galvanostatic cycling with symmetrical Li/CE/Li cell on LAND CT2001A battery system (Wuhan LAND Electronics Co., Ltd.). The testing current density ranged from 0.05 mA cm−2 to 0.2 mA cm−2 (0.5 h for per plating/stripping process).

The electrochemical performance of the solid-state battery was examined on LAND CT2001A battery system at different C-rates (1C = 170 mA g−1). Unless otherwise noted, all the cells were tested at room temperature.

The structure and morphology characterization results are given in Fig. 2 . Fig. 2a shows the XRD patterns of LLZTO powder, PVDF-HFP powder and composite electrolytes. The diffraction peaks of the LLZTO ceramic powder match with the standard card of a cubic crystalline Li5La3Nb2O12 phase (JCPDS#80–0457), which has a higher lithium-ion conductivity than the tetragonal phase [57,58]. While mixed with polymer matrix, the peaks of LLZTO remain unchanged, indicating the good chemical stability between LLZTO and the polymer matrix.

Fig. 2b demonstrates the CE15 membrane at a highly bent state. When clamp is released, the CE membrane can fully recover to the original state, showing a good flexibility nature of the composite electrolyte, which has potential applications in flexible electronics, etc [59–61]. Interestingly, Fig. 2c reveals that the color of the CE membrane becomes darker as the content of LLZTO increases. The membrane is highly transparent with 0% of LLZTO, while with 30% of LLZTO the membrane appears to be dark brownish. The change of color is attributed to the fact that La atom of LLZTO could form complex with CO group and N atom of DMF solvent, which induces the chemical dehydrofluorination of the PVDF-HFP skeleton [46].

The microscopic morphology of the CE10 membrane is given in Fig. 2d and g. There is no obvious crack, pore or aggregates on the planar surface (Fig. 2d) and cross-section (Fig. 2g) of the composite electrolyte membrane, showing compact and uniform mixing of the polymer and ceramic. The thickness of the composite electrolyte membrane can be estimated to be around 50 μm. Relatively uniform distributions of Zr and F elements can be observed from the EDS mapping images (Fig. 2e and f), implying that both ceramic and polymer are well mixed in the electrolyte membranes.

Thermogravimetric analysis was performed to determine the thermal stability of the composite electrolyte membrane. As shown in Fig. 2h, a small amount of mass loss can be observed in the early stage of heating (~100 °C), which is attributed to the volatilization of water or crystal water in the electrolyte as well as the vaporization of residual DMF solvent in the system [62,63]. When the temperature rises to 300–350 °C, there's a sharp drop in the weight of electrolyte membrane, which is due to the decomposition process of PVDF-HFP and LiTFSI [64]. The thermal decomposition temperature of CE0 and CE15 can be extrapolated to be ~310 °C and 340 °C, respectively, indicating that the addition of LLZTO ceramic filler is beneficial to promote the thermal stability of polymer matrix composite electrolyte.

Fig. 2i displays DSC curves of the composite electrolytes, the endothermic peak observed at 130–140 °C is related to the melting of PVDF-HFP of the electrolytes. It can be seen, with the addition of LLZTO particle, the melting temperature (Tm) of PVDF-HFP reduced from 136.5 °C to 130.1 °C, and the area of the crystalline melting peak decreases. These suggest that the degree of crystallinity of PVDF-HFP decreased due to the introduction of LLZTO particle. To further evaluate the relative crystallization of the composite electrolyte, the degree of crystallinity (χc) is introduced, which can be calculated by Eq. (3): [65].
(3)
χ c
=
∆
H m
∆
H m 0
f
PVDF − HFP
× 100 %
where ∆H
m is the melting enthalpy of composite electrolyte, ∆H
m
0 is the melting enthalpy value for a fully crystallized PVDF-HFP (104.7 J g−1) [66,67], and f
PVDF−HFP is the PVDF-HFP mass percentage in the composite electrolyte. Compared to CE0, χ c of CE15 was found to decrease from 40% to 23% with the addition of LLZTO particles. This demonstrates that the addition of LLZTO can destroy the polymer crystallization and reduce the crystallization degree, which could help to improve the segmental motion of the polymer network, thus benefiting ionic transfer.

The mechanical properties of the composite electrolyte also play a critical role in preventing dendrite formation in lithium metal batteries. Solid electrolyte with good mechanical properties can suppress the growth of lithium dendrites and ensure the safety and stability of solid-state lithium batteries [68,69]. Fig. S2 shows the typical stress-strain curves of composite electrolytes under tensile test. It can be observed that CE0 has a yield strength of ~7 MPa, a rapture stress/strain of 12.5 MPa/240%, and Young's modulus of 37.6 MPa. After the addition of LLZTO, the mechanical strength of CE15 is improved with a yield strength of ~10 MPa, a rapture stress/strain of 13.2 MPa/150% and Young's modulus of 52.1 MPa, which are superior to those of electrolyte membranes reported previously [26,42,46]. The improved mechanical strength can be attributed to the adhesion effect between the PVDF-HFP matrix and ceramic LLZTO particles. The composite electrolytes with superior mechanical properties could largely suppress the growth of lithium dendrite and improve battery safety.

The ionic conductivities of composite electrolytes with different contents of LLZTO nanoparticles at temperatures from 25 °C to 80 °C are investigated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements (Fig. 3 ). The corresponding Nyquist plots of CE0 and CE15 at different temperatures are plotted in Fig. 3a and b, respectively. It is revealed that for both samples, the increase of temperature could largely decrease the impedance, which can be understood since the ionic conductivity increases with increasing temperature for semiconducting oxides [14]. The ionic conductivity can be extracted from the impedance data, as given in Fig. 3c. At the given temperature, within the range of 0% to 30% LLZTO content, the ionic conductivity increases first and then decreases with increasing LLZTO content. When the content of LLZTO is 15 wt%, composite electrolyte shows the highest ionic conductivity, which is 3.2 × 10−4 S.cm−1 at 25 °C. It is comparable to the previous reports [42,70]. The initial increase of ionic conductivity with addition of LLZTO can be attributed to the higher ionic conductivity of the LLZTO particle (~ 10−3–10−4 S.cm−1) [27], as well as lower crystallinity of PVDF-HFP, while the later decrease of ionic conductivity may attribute to the aggregation of the nanoparticles at a high weight ratio [71,72] which gives rise to a higher ratio of solid/solid interfaces as well as more polymer/ceramic interface that could hinder the transport of Li+ ion [70,73].

The Arrhenius plots of the composite electrolytes with various weight fractions of LLZTO are shown in Fig. 3d to estimate the activation energy for Li-diffusion. According to the classic Arrhenius equation σ
T
= A
exp
−
E a
RT
, the activation energy E
a was calculated and listed in Table 1 . Lower E
a indicates a lower diffusion barrier for Li+ ion migration. It can be calculated that E
a for CE10 and CE15 are 0.23 eV and 0.24 eV, respectively, which are lower than CE0 (0.30 eV) and CE30 (0.32 eV).

The electrochemical stability window is an important parameter for characterizing the electrochemical stability and safety of the composite electrolytes. As shown in Fig. 4a, as compared to PVDF-HFP/LiTFSI electrolyte, the decomposition voltage of PVDF-HFP/LiTFSI/CE15 can be largely increased from ~4.7 V to ~5 V. This shows that the addition of LLZTO ceramic particles improves the electrochemical stability of the polymer matrix. Since the working voltage range of the current commercial lithium batteries is generally 2.0–4.3 V, this composite electrolyte can meet the practical application needs of the lithium batteries. Besides, with improved electrochemical window, this composite electrolyte can be utilized towards high-voltage lithium battery.

Another critical factor for electrolyte is the transference number of the cation, namely t
Li + . The transference number is an indicator for the Li+ ion transfer ability in the electrolyte, which provides information about the rate capability contribution of the Li+ ions in the electrolyte [42]. As shown in Fig. 4b, the calculated t
Li + of the composite solid electrolyte is 0.66 at room temperature, which is higher than that of the liquid electrolyte (0.35) [74] and comparable or higher than the state-of-art solid electrolytes [56,75]. The major improvement is attributed to the LLZTO filler, which is an active lithium-ion conductor with a transference number of 1 [70,76]. LLZTO particles can favor interactions with the PVDF-HFP segments and the lithium salt anion (TFSI−), increase the dissociation of lithium salt and enhance the lithium-ion transference number [42].

The electrochemical testing results of the Li/CE/LiFePO4 full cells are given in Fig. 5 . Fig. 5a shows the first charge-discharge curves of Li/CE/LiFePO4 cells. The cell with CE15 (red line) has a smaller polarization as compared to CE0 (blue line), which is related to the higher ionic conductivity. The cycling performances at 0.1C (1C = 170 mA g−1, between 2.5 and 4.0 V) are further given in Fig. 5b and c. The specific discharge capacity of Li/CE15/LFP cell can achieve 147 mA h g−1 in the first cycle and the coulombic efficiency maintains nearly 99% after 50 charge/discharge cycles. Meanwhile, the capacity retention of Li/CE0/LFP cell is only 54.2% after 50 cycles. This indicates that the addition of LLZTO can significantly improve the battery electrochemical performance.

Long-term galvanostatic stripping/plating of Li/CE15/Li symmetric cell at room temperature was carried out to evaluate the compatibility of the CE with Li metal electrode. Fig. 5d exhibits the cycling performance of the cell under different current densities, and in each cycle, the cell was charged and discharged for 0.5 h, respectively. The initial average potential at 0.05 mA cm−2 was 10 mV. When the current density increased to 0.1 mA cm−2 and 0.2 mA cm−2, the average potential increased to 25 mV and 50 mV, respectively. During the whole cycling process, the voltage profiles are stable and have no sign of short-circuiting. It is clearly shown that the formation of lithium dendrites can be suppressed with the composite electrolyte used in this study.

Fig. 6a compares the rate capacity of Li/CE/LiFePO4 cells using LFP and LFP-new cathodes. At low C-rate, both cells demonstrate similar capacity; meanwhile, LFP-new shows improved performance at relatively higher C-rate, with 40% capacity increase at 2C. Fig. 6b shows charge-discharge curve of the Li/CE/LFP-new cell under different C-rates. The specific capacity of Li/CE/LFP-new cell at 0.1C, 0.5C and 2C can achieve 144, 113 and 81 mAh g−1, respectively. This improved rate performance can be attributed to the following reasons. On the one hand, the addition of LiTFSI can enhance the ionic conductivity of the LFP cathode and establish a good ionic conductive network inside the electrode [75]. On the other hand, PVDF-HFP is used as binder for both the LFP cathode and the solid electrolyte, which can improve interfacial contact and compatibility between the electrolyte and cathode in the cell, resulting in lower interfacial resistance [77]. As shown in Fig. S5, the semicircle of cell with new cathode in the intermediate frequency region is smaller than conventional cathode, which proves the reduction of the interface resistance between the solid electrolyte and cathode.

In summary, PVDF-HFP/LLZTO solid state composite electrolytes were synthesized via a facilitative and cost-effective method. The addition of LLZTO particles can improve both the thermal stability and the electrochemical performance of the solid electrolyte. The as-prepared CE exhibits high ionic conductivity (3.2 × 10−4 S.cm−1), wide electrochemical window (4.98 V) and high lithium-ion transfer number (0.66) at room temperature. Furthermore, a new LFP cathode with PVDF-HFP as binder and LiTFSI added demonstrates a better rate capacity than conventional LFP cathode, which delivered a ~ 40% capacity increase at 2C, using PVDF-HFP/LLZTO composite electrolyte. We hope this work could spur further interests in polymer/conducting oxides composite electrolytes for enabling high energy density lithium metal batteries.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare no conflict of interest.

(b) Rate performance of Li/CE15/LFP cell; Fig. S5. Rate capability of Li/CE/LFP cell and Li/CE/ LFP-new cell; Fig. S6 Nyquist plots of the Li/CE/LFP cell and Li/CE/LFP-new cell.
